Tonight, I proudly cast my vote for the REINS Act, H.R. 26, which will improve accountability and reduce big government.  During the Obama Administration, more than 550 rules and regulations have been passed without oversight or accountability.  Compliance costs are $2 trillion, and affect every household.  The REINS Act would require costly executive rules or regulations to come before Congress.

Here is a list of the bills the House of Representatives considered this week.  I’m especially pleased to vote for bills that support our veterans, and the bills that will reduce the harmful effects of executive-branch rules and regulations that by-pass Congressional review.   H.R. 26– Regulations from the Executive in Need of Scrutiny Act of 2017 - This legislation curbs unnecessary major regulations from unaccountable bureaucrats by requiring agencies to submit major regulations, those costing more than $100 million in economic effect, to Congress for approval. It also guarantees fast up or down votes on major rules, as Congress must act within 70 legislative days.   .  I voted YES.   H.R. 71– Taxpayers Right-To-Know Act – This legislation would increase information and taxpayer transparency regarding the cost and performance of certain federal programs.  .  I voted YES.  H.R. 21– Midnight Rules Relief Act of 2017 - This legislation solves the problem of midnight rules with one simple stroke, amending the Congressional Review Act to allow CRA resolutions that disapprove of multiple midnight rules simultaneously by the incoming Congress. It sets neither a minimum nor a maximum number of midnight rules that a CRA resolution can disapprove.  .  I voted YES.  H.R. 21-Ensuring VA Employee Accountability Act - This legislation takes the next steps vital to improving our Veterans Administration by granting the Department greater flexibility in removing employees based on poor performance or misconduct, while strengthening accountability and evaluation measures for all employees.  I voted YES.  H.R. 28– Biological Implant Tracking and Veteran Safety Act of 2017 - This legislation will direct the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to adopt the FDA's unique device identification system for labeling all biological implants and to implement an automated inventory system to ensure veterans do not receive expired or otherwise contaminated tissue.  .  I voted YES.

There will be a stable transition to a better, 21st century health care system, unlike the implementation of the ACA.   Obamacare has failed, and it’s only getting worse. This is legislation and how I voted in the House of Representatives this week:   S.J. Res. 34 - Providing Disapproval of the rule submitted by the Federal Communications Commission relating to Protecting the Privacy of Customers of Broadband and Other Telecommunications Services. This bill corrects executive overreach that improperly addressed internet privacy imposed by the FCC, an area more properly handled by the Federal Trade Commission. The regulations targeted only select internet providers, like Verizon and Comcast, but excluded other major data collectors like Google and Facebook.  The overreach and incomplete coverage of the rule made it essentially ineffective.   Internet privacy is an important concern, which demands airtight legislation. The Energy and Commerce Committee is examining this issues closely, and I look forward to what it's recommendations for protecting Americans' privacy will be.  I voted YES. Renewable energy is a part of our future.  That's why I cosponsored this bill in the House of Representatives:   H.R. 825, Public Land Renewable Energy Development Act of 2017, Rep. Paul Gosar [R-AZ] This bipartisan legislation would expedite the permitting process for renewable energy development on public lands. It would also direct money collected from renewable energy projects to states, counties, and conservation programs. Ultimately, the bill seeks to incentivize clean energy production on public lands and ensure local communities reap the benefits.

Firefighters have a risky job--every day and in the long run. Cancer rates for firefighters are a reason I cosponsored this bill in the House of Representatives this week:   H.R. 931, Firefighter Cancer Registry Act of 2017, Rep. Chris Collins [R-NY] This bill would require the CDC to create a voluntary registry of firefighters to collect history and occupational information that can be linked to existing data in state cancer registries. Firefighters currently experience significantly higher rates of certain types of cancer, but little research has been done to explain why. The registry would be used to improve monitoring of cancer among firefighters and the CDC would then develop guidance for states to effectively use the registry to implement practices designed to reduce cancer rates.

I cosponsored this bill will help hold Iran accountable for activity relating to ballistic missiles:   H.R. 1698, Iran Ballistic Missiles and International Sanctions Enforcement Act, Rep. Ed Royce [R-CA] H.R. 1698 would impose additional sanctions against Iran for violating UN Security Council Resolution 2231, which prohibits Iran from undertaking any activity relating to ballistic missiles. Shortly after enacting the JCPOA, Iran tested ballistic missiles capable of delivering nuclear warheads. Holding them accountable for such actions would send a clear message that the JCPOA does not enable them to do as they please, and that their other obligations still stand.

Today I kept a promise to Utah’s 4th District by voting to repeal and replace Obamacare with a viable alternative. Passage of the American Health Care Act (H.R. 1628) comes at a crucial time, as Americans continue to face increasing premiums and fewer choices.   One third of US counties have only one insurance provider. Several insurers are looking to withdraw from the exchanges, leaving Americans who buy their own insurance without options. Meanwhile, more than 30 million Americans skip doctor visits to avoid high costs, even with coverage.  Premiums are expected to skyrocket 22% this year. Recently, one young family told me that they realized that they couldn’t afford the massive $8,000 deductible associated with their daughter’s RSV check.   Unfortunately, these stories are not uncommon, and they show why maintaining the status quo is unacceptable.  My vote for the American Health Care Act (AHCA) is the beginning of the process to give Utahns access to quality and affordable healthcare, revamp the insurance markets and provide stability to those who do not have it.  It does this by giving the decisions and resources to the states and individuals rather than the federal government.  The federal government often dictates regulations to states like Utah, claiming to have a better answer than the people who live here.  Utahns will do much better than the federal government deciding what is best for them and their healthcare.    The AHCA also empowers states to control how they use their Medicaid funds.  It gives those without health insurance tax credits to buy the health insurance of their choosing allowing more market forces to be at play when it comes to choice of plans.  It also preserves protections for people with pre-existing conditions while giving states greater flexibility to lower premiums and stabilize the insurance market.   This is a first step.  I am committed to achieving a 21st century healthcare system that lowers costs, improves access and increases quality for Americans.

H.R. 10, The financial CHOICE Act: This is major legislation that has been a major priority for GOP members of the Financial Services Committee.   I voted YES.   Details:  This bill is a better way forward for America’s financial laws.  The CHOICE Act replaces the Dodd-Frank Act.   After the 2008 financial crisis and resulting recession, Dodd-Frank promised reform.  Instead of lifting the economy, Dodd-Frank resulted in the slowest, weakest recovery in 70 years. Instead of ending taxpayer-funded bailouts, Wall Street bailouts were enshrined into law. Dodd-Frank promised to make the financial system safer, but big banks got even bigger, and small banks and credit unions became fewer. Consumers were supposed to be protected, but in fact Dodd-Frank resulted in higher bank fees, more expensive mortgages, fewer choices and the most unaccountable government agency in U.S. history. The Financial CHOICE Act would: End taxpayer-funded bailouts once and for all and ensure no company is ‘too big to fail’. Hold Wall Street accountable with the toughest penalties in history for fraud and deception. Reclaim power from the administrative state and give it back to the people and their representatives. Rein in the rogue Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) to empower all Americans to achieve financial independence. Unleash opportunities for Main Street small businesses, innovators and job creators by eliminating onerous Washington regulations that are stifling access to credit and capital.    Also this week:   H.R. 2213, Anti Border Corruption Reauthorization Act of 2017:  Border Patrol Agents and Customs Officers perform critical work, but are understaffed. There were several Veterans-related bills the House of Representatives voted on this week, in addition to important legislation that encourages the expansion of hydropower generation facilities.   H.R. 4173 - Veterans Crisis Line Study Act of 2017, as amended  This bill would direct the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to conduct a study on the outcomes and the efficacy of the Veterans Crisis Line based on analysis of national suicide data and data collected from the Veterans Crisis Line. I voted YES.  H.R. 3705 - Veterans Fair Debt Notice Act of 2017, as amended This bill would require the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) work with Veterans Service Organizations (VSOs) to develop new notification that, in plain language, clearly explain why such alleged debt was created, and the steps the veteran can take to dispute or mitigate the debt. I voted YES.  H.R. 918 - Veteran Urgent Access to Mental Healthcare Act, as amended  This bill would provide mental health care to certain former service members who would otherwise be ineligible for such care because they were discharged from military service under conditions that were other than honorable (OTH).  I voted YES.  H.R. 1133 - Veterans Transplant Coverage Act of 2017 This bill would amend the Choice program to authorize the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to provide for any care and/or services a live donor may require to carry out a transplant procedure at a medical facility in the community for an eligible veteran notwithstanding that the live donor may not be eligible for VA care. I voted YES.  H.R. 3043 - Hydropower Policy Modernization Act of 2017  This bill modernizes the regulatory permitting process and encourages the expansion of hydropower generation by improving administrative efficiency, accountability, and transparency; promotes new hydropower infrastructure; requires balanced and timely decision making; and reduces duplicative oversight. Specifically, the legislation establishes the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission as the lead agency for all hydropower authorizations, approvals, and requirements mandated by federal law. The bill modifies the definition of renewable energy to include hydropower, extends the timeframe for a preliminary permit from 3 to 4 years, and extends the time limit for construction “for not more than 8 additional years. I voted YES.  H.R. 2201 - Micro Offering Safe Harbor Act This bill amends the Securities Act of 1933 to exempt certain micro-offering from the Act's registration requirements. I voted YES.

This week I voted on H.R. 1699 - Preserving Access to Manufactured Housing Act -- This will allow consumers of small-balance residential loans to have increased access to mortgage credit. The bill amends the Truth in Lending Act (15 U.S.C. 1601) to allow for the first mortgage on a homeowner’s principal home to not be considered “high cost” if (1) the mortgage annual percentage rate (APR), at the time of consummation of the loan, does not exceed 10 percent of the average prime offer rate (APOR)(2) the transaction does not exceed $75,000 and, (3) the mortgage points and fees paid to the mortgage originator do not exceed 5 percent of the transaction or $3,000. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) will have the ability to adjust designated amounts to reflect changes in the Consumer Price Index (CPI).  I voted YES.
